hints: A classic block-stacking puzzle game.
The falling shapes are called Tetriminos.
It was created by a Russian video game designer.
A first-person puzzle-platformer.
You use a special gun to create linked doorways.
Features a sarcastic AI named GLaDOS.
A classic point-and-click adventure game.
It was a groundbreaking game for its detailed worlds.
You explore a mysterious island.
A popular match-three puzzle video game.
Involves swapping adjacent gems.
Developed by PopCap Games.
A classic logic puzzle game.
The goal is to clear a grid without detonating hidden items.
Numbers on the grid indicate how many of these are nearby.
A logic-based number-placement puzzle.
You fill a 9x9 grid with digits.
Each row, column, and 3x3 subgrid must contain digits 1 to 9.
A puzzle-platformer with a time manipulation mechanic.
You can rewind time to solve puzzles.
Known for its impressionistic art style.
An indie puzzle-platform game.
The main character is a small white cube.
You rotate the world to change your perspective.
A puzzle-platformer and adventure game.
Known for its dark, monochromatic art style.
You play as a boy searching for his sister.
A word puzzle that takes the form of a grid.
You fill in blank squares with words.
The clues are typically provided in a numbered list.
A puzzle consisting of interlocking and tessellating pieces.
The pieces form a complete image when assembled.
Often used for recreation.
A 3D combination puzzle.
It was invented by a Hungarian sculptor.
The goal is to get each side to a solid color.
A two-player strategy board game.
Each player starts with sixteen pieces.
The goal is to checkmate the opponent's king.
A card game that can be played by one person.
The goal is to stack all cards into foundation piles.
A common version is Klondike.
A Japanese mathematical and logical puzzle.
The grid size can vary, such as 3x3 or 4x4.
It involves arithmetic operations within cages.
A dissection puzzle from China.
Consists of seven flat polygons.
The goal is to form a specific shape using all seven pieces.
A picture logic puzzle.
Also known as Hanjie or Griddlers.
The goal is to reveal a hidden picture on a grid.
A common item in many puzzle games.
Can be matched or cleared for points.
Often appears as a sparkly stone.
A square or rectangular piece used on a game board.
Can be matched, swapped, or moved.
Found in games like Mahjong and Candy Crush.
A pattern of horizontal and vertical lines.
The playing area in most puzzle games.
Used in games like Sudoku and Minesweeper.
A question or statement phrased as a puzzle.
Requires clever thinking to solve.
Often used as a plot device in adventure games.
A piece of information that helps to solve a puzzle.
Can be a word, picture, or sound.
Essential for progression in many games.
A game or toy designed to test ingenuity.
Requires players to find a solution.
The core mechanic of the genre.
A type of puzzle that requires lateral thinking.
Often takes the form of a riddle.
Challenges your mind with a problem.
A common shape in many puzzle games.
Can be stacked, moved, or destroyed.
The main piece in games like Tetris and Qbert.
A confusing network of paths.
The goal is to find your way from one point to another.
Used as a puzzle in many games.
An item used to unlock something.
Can be a physical object or a digital item.
A classic puzzle element in adventure games.
A mechanism used to secure a door or object.
Requires a specific item to open it.
A common obstacle in an escape room.
A series of numbers or symbols.
Used to unlock doors, safes, or chests.
Can be found hidden in the game world.
A genre of puzzle game.
The goal is to find a list of items in a picture.
Often features intricate scenes.
A type of puzzle game where players are locked in a room.
You must find clues to solve puzzles to get out.
Can be a physical or video game experience.
A type of adventure game.
The player interacts with the world using a cursor.
Used in games like Myst and Day of the Tentacle.
A subgenre of puzzle video games.
Players match at least three similar items.
Candy Crush is a famous example.
A type of puzzle game where you use real-world forces.
You manipulate gravity, momentum, or other forces.
Angry Birds and World of Goo are examples.
A tiny square dot on a screen.
A common art style in indie puzzle games.
Fez and The Binding of Isaac use this style.
A button or lever that changes something in the game world.
Can open doors or change the environment.
A classic puzzle game element.
A casino game of chance.
A ball is dropped onto a spinning wheel.
A puzzle in some video games.
A type of puzzle that relies on deduction and reasoning.
Does not rely on chance or dexterity.
Sudoku is a prime example.
A Nintendo DS game.
Consists of mini-games to improve brain function.
The full title includes 'Dr. Kawashima's'.
A Japanese tile-matching game.
Involves dropping and stacking colored blobs.
It often features a competitive mode against another player.
A game that combines match-three with role-playing elements.
You cast spells and defeat enemies by matching gems.
The original game was released in 2007.
A physics-based puzzle video game.
You build structures using balls of black fluid.
Developed by 2D Boy.
A physics-based puzzle game.
You use a slingshot to launch characters at structures.
The characters are different types of birds.
A puzzle game where you guide a princess through optical illusions.
Known for its surreal architecture.
Inspired by M.C. Escher.
A popular mobile match-three game.
You match colorful sweets.
Developed by King.
A mobile puzzle game.
You combine numbers by sliding tiles.
Inspired the later game 2048.
A single-player puzzle game.
You slide numbered tiles on a grid to combine them.
The goal is to reach a tile with a certain number.
A 3D puzzle game where you explore an island.
You solve line-based puzzles on panels.
There are no tutorials and no spoken dialogue.
An iconic first-person shooter game.
It features a level called 'The Citadel' with a puzzle to open the doors.
Not primarily a puzzle game, but has a famous puzzle level.
A common obstacle in puzzle games.
Often requires a key, code, or button to open.
A classic element of adventure games.
Anything that prevents progress in a puzzle.
Can be a wall, a locked gate, or an enemy.
Something you must overcome to succeed.
A mechanism used to activate or deactivate something.
Often used to open doors or control platforms.
A classic puzzle element in platformers.
A simple machine used to lift or move something.
Can be pulled to trigger an event.
Similar to a switch.
A clickable object that performs an action.
Can be found on the floor or a wall.
A staple of puzzle-platformers.
A sequence of symbols or numbers.
Must be entered correctly to solve a puzzle.
Used to open a locked safe or door.
A locked metal box for storing valuables.
Requires a combination to open.
A common puzzle in escape room games.
A tile-based game of Chinese origin.
Often played in a solitaire format.
The goal is to match pairs of tiles.
A puzzle where pictures and symbols represent words.
You have to decipher the hidden message.
A common form of word puzzle.
A type of puzzle that consists of a short encrypted text.
Each letter has been replaced by another.
The goal is to decipher the original message.
A type of deduction puzzle.
You use a grid to organize clues and eliminate possibilities.
Often involves a list of people, items, and locations.
Building elements in games like Minecraft.
Can be used to build structures or solve puzzles.
Also the main component of Tetris.
A common type of jewel in puzzle games.
Often matched to clear the board.
A key item in games like Bejeweled.
A container that requires a specific sequence of moves to open.
Can be a physical object or a game element.
Often contains a reward or a clue.
A break or split in the environment.
Can be used for teleportation.
A mechanic in games like Portal.
A character who navigates a labyrinth.
The main character in the Maze Runner books.
Used to describe players in a maze-based game.
A list of items a player is carrying.
You often need to combine items to solve a puzzle.
Crucial in point-and-click adventure games.
A symbolic figure or a carved character.
Often used as part of a code or password.
Can be a puzzle element in games like The Witness.
A method of encrypting a message.
Used as a puzzle to reveal a secret.
Requires a key to decode.
A mystical symbol.
Often used in fantasy games as a puzzle element.
Can be activated in a specific order.
A clue or suggestion to help solve a puzzle.
Can be a subtle piece of information in the game world.
Provided to assist a player.
A genre that combines two game types.
Requires jumping and timing as well as problem-solving.
Examples include Braid and Limbo.
A genre that often includes puzzle-solving.
Players explore a world and interact with characters.
The Legend of Zelda is a classic example.
The goal of many puzzle games.
To find a way out of a confined space.
The main objective in an escape room.
A point-and-click adventure game.
The main character is a robot.
Known for its beautiful hand-drawn art.
A strategy and maze-based arcade game.
You place explosives to clear a path.
The goal is to defeat opponents.
A common mechanic in tile puzzles.
You move a piece by pushing it.
Used in a type of puzzle box.
A word-guessing party game.
One person draws a picture to represent a word.
The team tries to guess the word.
An electronic memory game.
Features four colored buttons.
Players must repeat a sequence of lights and sounds.
A code-breaking board game.
One player sets a code of colored pegs.
The other player tries to guess it.
A tile-based puzzle game.
You match pairs of tiles to clear them.
It is often played in a solitaire version.
A strategy board game for up to six players.
The goal is to move all your marbles to the opposite side.
Despite the name, it is not of Chinese origin.
A game played with rectangular tiles.
Each tile has two ends marked with a number of spots.
Players connect tiles by matching the numbers.
An abstract strategy board game.
It originated in ancient China.
The goal is to surround more territory than your opponent.
A strategy board game for two players.
Pieces can only move diagonally.
The goal is to capture all of the opponent's pieces.
A complex machine designed to perform a simple task.
Named after a famous cartoonist.
Often a type of puzzle in video games.
A common platform for puzzle games.
A type of e-reader.

A tablet computer.

The category for this list.
A form of play or sport.
Includes genres like action, adventure, and puzzle.

A text-based adventure game.
Involves solving puzzles through typing commands.
A genre of puzzle game.
The goal is to solve a crime or an unknown event.

A classic murder mystery board game.
Players must deduce the culprit, weapon, and location.
Also known as Clue.
A strategy board game.
The goal is to move all your tokens to the home column.
A version of the Indian game Pachisi.
A word board game.
Players form words from letters on tiles.
Words are scored based on their value.
A word game played with a tray of letter cubes.
Players try to find words in a 4x4 or 5x5 grid.
The words must be connected.
A logic puzzle.
Also known as Nonograms.
You use numbers to fill in a grid and reveal a picture.
Another name for Nonograms.
